keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 after being extradited from France.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, waited over a decade to pursue charges due to systemic delays and the destruction of critical evidence, including a rape kit.
Cleary sent a Facebook message in 2019 that said 'So I raped you,' which served as a trigger for renewed legal action.
The case illustrates how campus sexual assault cases often face obstacles in prosecution, especially due to lack of institutional support and lost evidence.
The judge considered Cleary’s guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness, resulting in a sentence below state guidelines.
Keeler’s public advocacy in a 2021 AP article helped expose broader issues of prosecutorial reluctance in campus sexual assault cases.
Cleary had a history of mental illness and was homeless at times, which defense counsel claimed, though prosecutors could not confirm he was on the run.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 for sexually assaulting a college student, Shannon Keeler, at Gettysburg College in 2013. The case took over a decade to resolve due to systemic challenges in prosecuting campus sexual assault, including lost evidence and prosecutorial reluctance. Cleary, who had lived in France and was briefly detained on a vagrancy charge in 2024, was extradited to Pennsylvania and pleaded guilty, expressing remorse and stating his commitment to mental health treatment. Keeler, the victim, revealed that the assault had been ignored for years and that the system failed her, despite her persistent efforts to pursue justice. The case underscores the broader issue of accountability in campus sexual violence and the emotional toll on survivors.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After 12-Year Wait for Justice in Campus Sexual Assault Case
